name: Ukraine
takeaway: Beijing’s relations with Kyiv were substantial until recently. China used to be the main trading partner of Ukraine, while the latter was one of the important suppliers of weapons to the PRC’s army. There were important Chinese investments in agri-business and technology sectors, and plans to develop BRI projects in transportation, ITC and urban infrastructure.

The large-scale aggression launched by Russia in 2022 significantly complicated relations: Ukraine became increasingly dependent on the West, while Beijing is leaning diplomatically towards Moscow. Nevertheless, Ukraine is cautious to avoid pushing the PRC even more towards Russia; while the PRC wants to keep the door open in Kyiv to protect existing investments and possibly take part in the future reconstruction effort.

The clamp-down on pro-Russian media and political actors after 2022 also indirectly reduced the PRC’s influence, since in terms of anti-Western rhetoric and propaganda there was a certain overlapping of channels.

The sector with the highest score is Technology, as before 2022 the telecom services were dominated by Russian companies, which were using plenty of equipment of Chinese origin. The large smart city projects based on Chinese technology were largely stopped by the war (for instance in Kharkiv) but the dependence on providers and equipment for mobile communication remains.
description-1: In 2023, Ukraine had a GDP per capita of US$5,181 and a total population of 38.02 million people.
description-2: Ukraine established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1992. Ukraine was ranked 61st in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Partly Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 49/100.

Media.evidence: There is a certain Ukrainian Chinese network, which, according to the databases, belongs to World Chinese Media, but its presence in the public space is negligible. Old information before 2015 may be outdated, especially after 02/24/2022. A lot has changed in the media landscape since the beginning of full-scale war: first of all, the change in public media consumption and the displacement of advertising.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: They exists formally, though the info about them is old and in the context of the war with Russia and Beijing's position on it, attitudes in UKR have toughened significantly, including in the media. Pro-Russian media / journalists were silenced, and to a large extent this network overlaps with the pro-China one, as the source quoted below makes clear.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: After 02/24/2024, the focus of society and the media shifted towards the war and defense of the country. Any measures or actions that are not in this context are not publicly announced. Accordingly, the cooperation of Ukrainian journalists and the media is evaluated based on data until February 24, 2022. No public confirmation of this was found.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: There is no observation of the Indicator phenomenon.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Media.evidence: Most of the mass media of the People's Republic of China do not have a Ukrainian-language version, but they have a Russian version that is understandable to most Ukrainians. But after the start of a full-scale war, the focus of media consumption changed, the main, active part of society switched to consuming Ukrainian-language media.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Foreign Policy.evidence: As of August 1, 2023, according to official data of the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine, the Ukraine-China interparliamentary relations group in the parliament consists of: 133 deputies out of 403. For example, the Ukraine-USA interparliamentary relations group consists of: 177 deputies out of 403.

Academia.evidence: Huawei has set up Seeds for the future program since 2016. Kyiv Polytechnic Institute, National University of Kyiv, Kyiv Mohyla Academy, Shevchenko National University of Kyiv, Kyiv National University of Technologies and Design are all included
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: Despite the full-scale invasion of Russia, they continue to work. In particular, the Confucius Institute at Kharkiv National University (KhNU) named after V.M. Karazin.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: Chinese (mandarin) is not on the approved list for the education system.

Academia.evidence: The official web pages do not list Ukrainian think tanks or research centers that are part of China-affiliated networks. But certain centers, such as the Association of Chinese Studies of Ukraine, behave as if they were part of it, which is absolutely loyal to China's interests in Ukraine. There is also V.I. Tauria National University named after Vernadskyi. The Taurian National University, opened in Kyiv after Russia's occupation of Crimea, states that it is part of the University Alliance of the Silk Road.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: Wang Jing, the head of Chinese government-affiliated Skyrizon, created and funded several organisations in Ukraine, which were active in 2015–2019. These are the Ukrainian Silk Road Association “Silk Link,” which positioned itself as a “B2B2G platform for business and political cooperation between Ukraine, China and European countries,” the “Tianxia Link” Center for Contemporary China, which aimed at deepening relations between Ukraine and China, the Ukrainian House in Beijing, and Xinwei Ukraine. Both suspended their activity after the failure of Skyrizon to get control over Motor Sich.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Academia.evidence: After the start of the full-scale invasion of Russia, restrictions were introduced on the possibility of movement of Ukrainian men abroad. Accordingly, such factors, as well as the very fact of a full-scale war and hostilities on the territory of Ukraine, limit the possibility of actions of programs such as the Thousand Talents Program or Changjiang Scholars program. We are not aware of such cases.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Until February 24, 2022, many regional authorities signed cooperation agreements with authorities in the PRC and Chinese companies. But after the full-scale invasion of Russia, such a practice is not observed.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Until February 24, 2022, many agreements were recorded between the entities of Ukraine and the People's Republic of China, which in one way or another provide for sisterly ties. But after the full-scale invasion of Russia, such a practice is not observed.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Domestic Politics.evidence: After the start of the full-scale invasion of Russia, restrictions were imposed on the movement of politicians and civil servants of Ukraine abroad. Accordingly, this limited the ability of the PRC or its representatives to invite Ukrainian politicians or civil servants. Currently, such facts are unknown.
Domestic Politics.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: According to the National Institute of Strategic Studies, the results of the first half of 2023 indicate that the main trading partner of Ukraine is the EU.

Economy.evidence: "In pre-war times, China was the primary buyer of Ukrainian raw materials. Last year, exports to China were carried out only during the first four months, after which Ukrainian suppliers, in the conditions of blocked ports, redirected exports to the nearest European markets of the Czech Republic, Poland, and Slovakia''.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Economy.evidence: PRC owns certain assets in Ukraine's infrastructure, however they are not critical or strategic. Aside from the Mykolaiv port PRC also owns some large cereals companies, other agrobusiness firms etc. However, none of these are critical at this point, they cannot buy land (but just lease it) and found their assets trapped in the war zones of Eastern Ukraine.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Technology.evidence: Experts claim that half of the base stations of the largest mobile operators — Kyivstar, Vodafone Ukraine, and Lifecell — are manufactured by Huawei. And in "Kyivstar", in principle, almost all stations are Chinese, since the second supplier is ZTE.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Technology.evidence: Until February 24, 2022, Chinese companies participated in various state projects, such as "safe cities" in Kyiv and Kharkiv and wi-fi for the Kyiv metro. After the start of a full-scale war, such projects do not meet the existing needs in Ukraine.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.
Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

Technology.evidence: Cameras in public spaces were installed years ago and they continued to function until short before the war. Reportedly some of these had facial recognition, but this is hard to confirm. It is not clear what happened to them after the Russian invasion in Feb 2022.

Society.evidence: Considering active hostilities and society's focus on war, most Ukrainian organizations focus on war or helping Ukraine in war. At the same time, due to the fact that the war, the visits of representatives of other countries are limited for security reasons. The same applies to the curtailment of programs outside the context of war or aid to Ukraine. In this regard, public information about any visits or cooperation with ACFTU.

Society.evidence: Considering active hostilities and society's focus on war, most Ukrainian organizations focus on war or helping Ukraine in war. At the same time, due to the fact that the war, the visits of representatives of other countries are limited for security reasons. The same applies to the curtailment of programs outside the context of war or aid to Ukraine. In this regard, no public information about any visits or cooperation at many levels in the journalistic and cultural sphere after 02/24/2022 has been found. Although until this date, the National Association of Journalists of China had a program of annual exchanges with the National Union of Journalists of Ukraine, including visits to China for Ukrainian journalists and to Ukraine for Chinese journalists.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.
